attributes.description: The protagonist, prince of Ayodhyá, described as the noblest lord of men and the destined heir of happiness.
attributes.lineage: Raghu's line, son of Dasaratha and Kauśalyá

attributes.description: The mother of Ráma and the first queen of King Dasaratha.
attributes.emotional_state: Distressed by her son's banishment, but ultimately supportive through blessings.

attributes.description: Ráma's wife, the daughter of King Janak of Videha; she insists on sharing her husband's exile.
The King of Ayodhyá, referred to as Kakutstha's son, who is forced by Fate and Kaikeyí's boons to exile Ráma.
The younger queen of Dasaratha whose art and boons lead to Ráma's banishment.
The brother of Ráma, son of Kaikeyí, appointed as the heir to the throne of Ayodhyá.
Ráma's younger brother, mentioned as one who should be loved by Sítá during the exile.
The sage who gifted celestial weapons to Ráma in the past.
The King of Gods, often invoked for protection and compared to the protagonist's strength.
The supreme deity mentioned in the context of his triple step in the Vamana (dwarf) avatar.
The inescapable force that dominates human life and drives the exile of Ráma.
The wild and vast forest where Ráma must spend his fourteen years of exile.
The capital city and home of the royal family from which Ráma is banished.
The nectar of immortality mentioned in the context of the struggle between Gods and Daityas.
A demon slain by Indra, mentioned to symbolize the victory of good over evil.

attributes.context: Mother and son relationship; characterized by filial duty and maternal grief.
Father and son; Ráma remains submissive to his father's decree despite the hardship.
Husband and wife; Sítá views him as her sole defense and deity.
Brothers; Bharat is appointed king in Ráma's absence.
Ráma is the subject of the exile decree.
Sítá insists on accompanying Ráma into the woods.
The location where the fourteen-year exile is to take place.
The city Ráma is preparing to leave.
She invokes the protection of the weapons Viśvámitra gave to Ráma.
Indra destroyed Vritra, an event used as a blessing for Ráma's success.
